title: Coronavirus crisis hits Massachusetts budget as revenues free fall and demand for services skyrockets
summary:
MTF on Tuesday released new tax revenue projections for the fiscal year that begins in July, predicting revenues would fall by $4.4 billion or 14.1 percent from the January 2020 benchmark.
“It’s sobering but not surprising,” Senate Ways and Means Committee Chairman Michael Rodrigues said.
That’s putting enormous pressure on state service,” Goodman said, citing a report that indicates the state could run out of money to pay jobless benefits within weeks.
Expert after expert echoed those concerns during a marathon three-hour virtual round-table discussion on Tuesday morning with Ways and Means Committee leaders and Administration and Finance Secretary Michael Heffernan.
“There’s no question that federal resources will be required if we want to ride this out in a way that minimizes human suffering,” Goodman.

title: Boston Speakers Series announces lineup for 2020-2021 Season
summary:
"This season of Lesley University's Boston Speakers Series is dynamic and diverse, both philosophically and experientially.
Tickets for the 2020-2021 Boston Speakers Series are available now by visiting www.BostonSpeakers.org.
As in years past, the series is sold by subscription only, offered on two series at Symphony Hall, a Monday Series and a Wednesday Series.
Presented by Lesley University, the Boston Speakers Series is sponsored by WGBH (89.7 FM) Boston Public Radio, the Boston Globe and DCU.
For more information about the 2020-2021 Boston Speakers Series, visit www.BostonSpeakers.org.

title: Cities Where Home Prices Plummeted as Early as February – 24
summary:
Home price data for March 2020 at the market level is not yet available, but already in February 2020, sales prices in a number of housing markets dipped.
To determine the cities where home prices are plummeting, 24/7 Wall St. reviewed the change in median sales price from January 2020 to February 2020 using data from ATTOM Data Solutions.
In a pair of markets, prices fell by well over 20%.
And those declines in many cases were particularly severe in many of the housing markets on this list.
Click here to see the cities where home prices plummeted as early as February

title: Conspiracy and false claims surrounding Dr. Charles Lieber, China and COVID-19 coronavirus
summary:
According to court documents, Dr. Lieber was the Principal Investigator of the Lieber Research Group at Harvard University.
The complaint alleges that Dr. Lieber worked with the University for significant periods between at least 2012 and 2017.Federal investigators also determined that Dr. Lieber was awarded more than $1.5 million to establish a nanotechnology research lab at WUT.
According to federal prosecutors, Dr. Lieber was in Wuhan years before it became the center of the coronavirus outbreak.
Dr. Lieber was arrested on Jan. 28, 2020, more than two months before the tweet was sent.Claim: “Charles Lieber @Harvard Univ.
Federal prosecutors have not alleged in any way that Dr. Lieber manufactured or sold viruses to China.

title: Trump, governors at odds on authority over coronavirus recovery path
summary:
In another assertion of authority Tuesday, Trump said he would halt funding to the World Health Organization while a review was conducted.
AdvertisementIn an apparent reference to the governors’ assertion of independence, Trump invoked the movie “Mutiny on the Bounty’’ in a tweet Tuesday.
Their strategy is part of a larger White House effort to draft a national plan to get Americans out of their homes and back to work.
Two White House officials said there was no broader planning for Trump’s comments that he had ‘‘total’’ authority.
“His authority is far from total.’’Material from David Abel of the Globe staff and the Associated Press was used in this report.

title: Man Killed in Head-On Car Crash in Rockland
summary:
A 40-year-old man was killed and two other men were injured Thursday afternoon in a head-on car crash in Rockland, Massachusetts.
The Plymouth County District Attorney’s Office said the crash happened shortly before 2 p.m. in a residential neighborhood on Route 123 when a Nissan hatchback and Mercedes sedan collided head-on.
All three men involved in the car crash were rushed to South Shore Hospital.
The driver of the Nissan, who was only identified as a 40-year-old man, died at the hospital.
Details on what led up to the crash were not immediately clear.

title: 7 snow maps predicting how much accumulation Mass. will see this weekend
summary:
Meteorologists are predicting a storm will bring accumulating snowfall to Massachusetts Saturday night, dropping a few inches around Boston with higher totals on the interior part of the state.
The National Weather Service said snow is forecast to start overspreading the region, from west to east, between 3 and 6 p.m.
“It is worth noting that given temperatures and the likely moderate to heavy snow intensity, snow should have little difficulty sticking/accumulating on roads,” forecasters warned.
pic.twitter.com/voRdvXcZzC — Dave Epstein (@growingwisdom) January 17, 2020Our next winter storm is on the way this weekend.
Saturday AM will be dry, but snow begins 3pm west, around 6pm east.

title: 5 New MA Laws That May Impact Your Life In 2020
summary:
Here's a look at five new laws taking hold in 2020 that could impact your life:Distracted drivingHands-free driving is finally upon Massachusetts motorists.
The law takes effect Feb. 23.
Massachusetts will be one of 24 states to boost the minimum wage in 2020, according to the National Employment Law Project.
Income tax reductionThe state's income tax will finally fall to 5 percent, 20 years after voters approved a ballot measure slashing the rate from what was then 5.85 percent.
The income tax in 2019 has been 5.05 percent.

title: UMass Boston student first confirmed case of coronavirus in Massachusetts
authors: Joe Dwinell Is Senior Editor At The Herald. If You Have A News Tip
Email Joed Bostonherald.Com Or Call You Can Also Mail In Tips To Joe Dwinell
summary:
A UMass Boston student returning to school from Wuhan, China, is the first confirmed case of the potentially deadly novel coronavirus in Massachusetts.
“We are working closely with the Massachusetts Department of Public Health (MDPH) and the Boston Public Health Commission (BPHC) to ensure all guidelines and protocols are diligently followed.
The UMass Boston student flew in from Wuhan the day before screening began, public health officials said.
Symptoms of novel coronavirus include fever, cough and shortness of breath, and, in severe cases, pneumonia (fluid in the lungs).
Additional details and guidance regarding the novel coronavirus, is available from the CDC: 2019 Novel Coronavirus.

title: Here’s the latest on the potential for accumulating snow this weekend
summary:
Forecasters are eyeing a weekend storm that’s shaping up to bring plowable snow to the entire region.
The latest National Weather Service map.
—NWS BostonThe National Weather Service’s latest forecast expects much of eastern Massachusetts to receive between two and six inches of snow from the storm, which begins Saturday afternoon.
“Precipitation ends late Saturday night into early Sunday morning,” the service’s forecasters wrote.
“Uncertainty remains on changeover timing, especially in Eastern Massachusetts and Rhode Island.”The storm is expected to change over to rain along the coast on Saturday evening.

title: Map: How much snow accumulated in Mass. from the overnight snowfall
summary:
Residents in parts of Massachusetts woke up Wednesday to a dusting of snow accumulation from an overnight weather system.
The snowfall tapered off across the Bay State between 4 and 7 a.m., according to the National Weather Service.
A few snow showers are possible today, as colder air moves in on gusty west-northwest winds.
pic.twitter.com/pWNuaaR2xZ — NWS Boston (@NWSBoston) January 8, 2020“Overnight snow resulted in a dusting to 1 inch across many locations south of the MA Turnpike,” service forecasters wrote.

title: Massachusetts Laws Taking Effect in 2020
summary:
With the start of the new year, some new laws will begin to impact residents in Massachusetts.
The hands-free driving law takes effect on Feb. 23.
Also taking effect in 2020 are a number of laws that will impact hundreds of thousands of Massachusetts workers.
Under the law, Massachusetts workers will be eligible to take up to 26 weeks of paid leave for medical or family reasons.
Charlie Baker approved a law that makes Massachusetts the first state in the country to ban flavored tobacco and vaping products.

title: ‘Here’s a reality check’: What forecasters are saying after the record warmth in Boston over the weekend
summary:
Winter weather is back in the forecast this week, after record-breaking warm temperatures over the weekend prompted Bostonians to set aside winter jackets for t-shirts and sandals.
[Record Highs] All 4 of our climate sites smashed their previous daily record max temps today!
#MAwx #RIwx #CTwx #AMS2020 pic.twitter.com/3zl6A5klbx — NWS Boston (@NWSBoston) January 11, 2020[5PM Record Highs] Not only did all of our 4 climate sites smash daily record highs for the 2nd straight day, #Boston and #Providence also set new all-time January record high temperatures!
74 on Sunday in Boston is now the all-time January monthly record, beating the 72 set in 1950.
Winter is making a comeback.’After record warmth over the weekend… cooler temps return this week.

title: The minimum wage in Massachusetts is going up this week. Here’s what you need to know.
summary:
Here’s what you need to know:How the minimum wage changes:First things first, the Massachusetts minimum wage, which increased from $11 to $12 last year, will go up again to $12.75 an hour in 2020.
It’s the second in the series of five annual minimum wage hikes.
By 2023, the Bay State will be joined by California, Connecticut, and Washington, D.C. — and parts of New York — with a $15 minimum wage.
There are, however, a few exceptions to the state’s standard minimum wage rate.
AdvertisementAlong with the standard minimum wage, the tipped minimum wage will increase Wednesday from $4.35 to $4.95 an hour (it had been $3.75 when the “grand bargain” was passed).

title: Confirmed Case Of Measles In Boston
summary:
BOSTON — After a Northeastern student who lives in Boston was diagnosed with measles Wednesday, health officials are warning people about potential exposure in 10 public places the infected person visited — from Logan Airport to Tatte's Bakery on Huntington Street to CVS on Massachusetts Avenue.
The Boston Public Health Commission said Thursday anyone who happened to be at those places could have been exposedThis is Boston's second confirmed case of measles in a city resident in the past three months.
Prior to that, there had been no cases of measles among Boston residents since 2013.
Anyone who was exposed and is unclear of their immunization status or begins to develop symptoms of measles should call their healthcare provider.
The CDC said there have been more than 314 measles cases across the country so far this year.

title: First Boston Baby Of 2020 Born At Midnight
summary:
BOSTON – The first baby of 2020 in Boston arrived just as the new year began on Wednesday, Jan. 1.
Baby Dominick was born at exactly midnight at Brigham and Women's Hospital.
The hospital said he and his mother Dannie are "resting comfortably."
Baby Dominick and his mother Dannie on January 1, 2020.
(Photo credit: Brigham and Women's Hospital)Read more at CBS Boston

title: Man Killed in Dorchester Shooting; Investigation Underway
summary:
A man was killed Wednesday evening in a shooting in Boston's Dorchester neighborhood.
Boston police said the shooting was reported just before 7:30 p.m. in the area of 1334 Dorchester Ave.
There, they found the male victim suffering from at least one gunshot wound.
The victim was taken to an area hospital in critical condition.
Details on what led up to the shooting were not immediately clear.

title: PIC Therapeutics Raises $5M in Seed Funding
summary:
PIC Therapeutics, a Boston, MA-based biotechnology company focused on transforming the treatment of cancer though the selective modulation of oncogene translation, closed a $5M seed equity funding.
The round was led by Advent Life Sciences with participation from Belinda Termeer, widow of Genzyme CEO Henri Termeer, as well as several biopharmaceutical industry executives and other individual investors.
The company intends to use the funds to advance its development ettorts.
Led by Sun Altbach, CEO, PIC Therapeutics is a biotechnology company focused on developing a new generation of therapeutics based on the modulation of RNA translation.

Rollins, in her press conference in November announcing the charges, “asserted many inaccuracies — even falsehoods,” Kim said.
“These quotes were carried by The Associated Press, by Reuters, by the local press.
“This basically tainted the jury pool.”Kim and PR company Rasky Partners flipped some texts to the media in the week before the arraignment, leading to the protective order.

title: 2-Vehicle Crash Leaves Debris Strewn Across Boston Road
summary:
A two-vehicle crash Monday evening left a man seriously injured and debris scattered across a Boston roadway.
The crash, along Franklin Park near the intersection of Morton and Canterbury streets on the Roxbury/Mattapan line, happened just before 6 p.m. and involved a Subaru Ascent and a Lexus sedan.
Massachusetts State Police say a 35-year-old Boston man was stopped on Morton Street and outside of his Subaru at the time of the crash.
The Lexus was driven by a 19-year-old from Quincy but police say they have no information on his injuries.
One lane of the street was closed to deal with the crash, while traffic was able to pass in another lane.

title: Mass. residents filed 20,000 unemployment claims Monday. That’s more than all of February
summary:
That single-day total exceeded the 17,382 claims the state handled all of last month, according to Charles Pearce, a spokesman for the Executive Office of Labor and Workforce Development.
Massachusetts residents filed nearly 20,000 new unemployment claims on Monday, topping the total from the entire month of February and providing an early sign of the sharp economic pain wrought by the spread of the novel coronavirus.
AdvertisementThe spike is unusual, even in bad economic times, when claims usually flow in over time as the economy slows down.
A worker doesn’t need to provide medical documentation, according to a new site the state launched to provide information on benefits amid the pandemic.

title: Biogen, host of Boston conference linked to dozens of coronavirus cases, donates $10M to pandemic response
summary:
The number of coronavirus cases in Massachusetts rose to 197 Monday, up from 164 on Sunday.
More than 100 of those cases have been linked to the Biogen conference, which was held at Marriott Long Wharf on Feb. 26 and 27 and drew an international roster of executives.
Biogen, the Cambridge-based biotech firm that hosted a late February conference in Boston linked to dozens of coronavirus cases, is donating $10 million to combat the pandemic.
Biogen said the donation will help nonprofits in Massachusetts and North Carolina, as well as Italy and other countries affected by the pandemic.
The company is also providing equipment and supplies to Partners HealthCare in Massachusetts to help diagnose Covid-19, the disease caused by coronavirus.

title: Massachusetts home prices up as winter eases, new figures show
summary:
In what will likely be the last statewide tea-leaves-reading of housing market figures before the novel coronavirus is factored in, new Massachusetts Association of Realtors numbers for February are out.
The number of single-family home sales in February dropped 6.9 percent year over year, to 2,493, according to MAR.
That’s a rare bright spot for buyers as it was the first time in nine months where the median sales price was below $400,000.
The increases came despite an inventory decline similar to that for single-families: 24.6 percent in the case of condos.
Whatever the February numbers, they seem like a coda not only for the winter market but for the Massachusetts housing market pre-coronavirus.

title: Bill Weld speaks out against Charlie Baker’s shutdown of recreational marijuana shops
summary:
Charlie Baker’s decision to shut down recreational marijuana shops during the coronavirus outbreak has drawn protests and a lawsuit from the cannabis industry.
And now the Massachusetts governor’s “mentor,” Bill Weld, has joined the critics.
“This has been widely—and correctly—viewed as a matter of social equity and economic justice,” Weld said.
Of the 11 states that legalized both medical and adult-use marijuana dispensaries, Massachusetts was the only state to make that distinction.
“Only Massachusetts has imposed this economic death sentence on small and previously disadvantaged business owners,” Weld wrote.

The Newton Chinese Language School, a nonprofit education organization registered in Massachusetts, organized two major coronavirus fundraising events in February, according to Fengfei Hu, school principal.
As the coronavirus broke out in Newton, the Newton Chinese Language School switched its focus from supporting Wuhan to helping the escalating situation in Newton.
The donors are not only the parents from the Newton Chinese Language School but also parents in Newton’s Chinese community, according to Liang.
Hua Fang, a Chinese immigrant and a father of two students at the Newton Chinese Language School, donated to the fundraiser right after the school sent out the newsletter.

title: Karen Jean Child
summary:
Karen Jean (Belisle) Child was released from her body on Friday, April 3rd, 2020, at home in West Tisbury, surrounded by her son, daughter, husband and incredible hospice nurse.
Karen married her best friend and devoted husband, Henry Teas Child of West Tisbury, whom she met at MVRHS.
On the Island, she worked for the Martha’s Vineyard Commission as an administrative assistant and the Martha’s Vineyard Shellfish Group with long-time dear friend Rick Karney.
After having her children, Karen worked as a daycare provider for Martha’s Vineyard Community Services and then preschool teacher at Green Gates Day School with Cecily Bryant.
She is survived by her beloved husband, Henry “Hal” Child, her son, Brandon Child and his wife Stephanie and their children Aiden and Mason, her daughter Bess Child and her husband Pietro Curini and their daughter Camilla, her sister-in-law, Janice Belisle and niece Julie Belisle.

summary:

The strong storm tracking across New England will bring “another round of mainly rain, changing to snow across interior Massachusetts before ending later this evening,” the National Weather Service said Friday.
“Expect light icing in the [Massachusetts] interior high elevations through this afternoon,” forecasters wrote.“The big story, however, is the potentially damaging winds this afternoon into evening.”The strongest winds are forecast over the state’s south coast and Cape Cod, where the service is predicting gusts between 60 and 70 mph will be possible.

title: This winter may end up tied for warmest Boston winter on record
summary:
Meteorological winter is defined as the months of December, January, and February.
During the 2019-2020 meteorological winter, the average temperature has been 37.8 degrees Fahrenheit, the same as 2001-2002, National Weather Service meteorologist Bill Simpson said.
With one day left in February, forecasters say this meteorological winter is on pace to tie 2001-2002 as the warmest winter on record in Boston.
“The weather service is still open for winter,” Simpson said.
There’s no indication that Boston will experience winter weather anytime soon, but Simpson didn’t rule out a return to colder temperatures.

title: Boston Scientist Says Actual COVID-19 Cases Could Approach 6,000 in Massachusetts
summary:
There are now over 200 confirmed cases of COVID-19 in Massachusetts, but the true number could be around 6,000, says Sam Scarpino, a professor of network science who heads up Northeastern University’s Emergent Epidemics Lab.
Scarpino and his colleagues have built a computer-generated model of coronavirus cases around the world and are now looking for effective measures that can be translated into a game plan for Massachusetts.
He says China has demonstrated that if we are prepared to take social distancing seriously here in the U.S., we should be able to lower the death rate from complications related to COVID-19.
Scarpino also warns that "flattening the curve" — the term used to describe lowering the surge of hospitalized patients, may also mean lengthening the time of the epidemic — a hard but necessary tradeoff.

title: One City’s Road to Recovery Offers Lessons, and Hope
summary:
This old textile-mill town, 30 miles north of Boston on the Merrimack River, was once a standard-bearer for America’s industrial power.
But for the many small cities that have long been left behind, struggling to find a place in the new economy, Lawrence offers a glimmer of hope that they may have a shot at recovery.
While there are empty storefronts and boarded windows downtown, the estimated value of the typical Lawrence home increased $100,000 over the last five years, to nearly $280,000, according to Zillow.
The high school dropout rate, nearly 30 percent a decade ago, is now under 12 percent.
And the income of the typical Lawrence family, which five years ago had tumbled to just over 55 percent of the median family income in the United States, inched back to 61 percent.

Hospitals in Greater Boston say the spread of coronavirus appears to be accelerating based on the number of patients they've seen in recent days.
The Boston Globe surveyed several hospitals, and most reported seeing an uptick in coronavirus patients on Tuesday.
Massachusetts General Hospital said the number of suspected COVID-19 patients quadrupled from Monday to Tuesday.
Beth Israel, Brigham and Women's and Boston Medical Center and Tufts Medical Center said they've also seen an increased number of patients this week.
Massachusetts is one of the states in the U.S. with the most coronavirus cases in the country so far.

title: New Rules For MA Grocery Stores, Pharmacies Amid Coronavirus
summary:
Charlie Baker issued new orders Wednesday related to grocery stores and pharmacies, two essential services.
The order includes a temporary drop of the statewide plastic bag ban, and a requirement that grocery stores and pharmacies provide at least an hour a day for shoppers older than 60 during the coronavirus public health emergency.
Although many were already doing this, the new order will require grocery stores and pharmacies to provide at least one hour per day for adults over 60 years old to shop.
The state also now requires grocery stores to offer sanitation options, such as hand sanitizer and disinfecting wipes, to clean shopping carts and points of frequent contact.
Lines at grocery stores should have the ground marked at 6 feet measurements at the check out and other places where lines might gather, like the deli, so that customers can practice safe social distancing.

title: There Are Now 8 Cases Of Coronavirus In Massachusetts
summary:
There are now eight total active cases of coronavirus in Massachusetts, the state's Department of Public Health reported Friday morning, up from the three cases reported Thursday evening.

Beyond the eight cases in Massachusetts, several people who traveled through Boston now have tested positive for the coronavirus, including a man in Tennessee, a man in Indiana and two people abroad, according to Massachusetts Secretary of Health and Human Services Marylou Sudders.
Three of the Suffolk County cases, two of the Norfolk County cases, the two international cases and the case in Tennessee are all connected to a recent Biogen conference in the state.

The price reduction hasn’t necessarily reached consumers yet, as March is typically an expensive month in which to buy live lobster because of lack of supply.

summary:
Two new presumptive positive cases of the highly contagious coronavirus have been reported in the Bay State, health officials announced on Thursday, raising the state’s count to one confirmed and three possible cases, forcing more people who were in contact to stay home.
The Massachusetts Department of Public Health confirmed a new presumptive positive case of coronavirus, a woman in her 60s who lives in Middlesex County and recently traveled to northern Italy.
South Shore Health also confirmed a presumptive positive case of coronavirus at Norwell’s South Shore Medical Center.
The Middlesex County and South Shore presumptive cases come on top of a Norfolk County presumptive case, a woman who had traveled from Italy, and the confirmed case of a UMass Boston student who traveled from Wuhan, China.
Also on Thursday, the Cambridge-based company Biogen announced that three employees who visited Boston last week have tested positive for coronavirus.

Health and Human Services Secretary Marylou Sudders will head up the command center, which will be the "single point" of decisions made regarding the administration's response.
A third commercial lab in Massachusetts is also getting approval to test for COVID-19, Sudders said.

title: Massachusetts home prices bounce in October
summary:
Single-family and condo prices in Massachusetts were up annually in October amid a shrinking supply of available homes to buy, according to new figures from the Massachusetts Association of Realtors.
The median single-family price was up year over year by 1.8 percent in October, to $400,000, and single-family sales were up 0.5 percent over the same period.
The median condo price in Massachusetts was up 4.2 percent, to $370,000, and sales were up 3.2 percent.
The realtors association expects the trend in higher prices to continue into 2020.
Single-family inventory was down more than 23 percent in October, and condo inventory was down more than 11 percent.

title: Tufts University becomes first urban Bee Campus USA in Massachusetts
summary:
Tufts University Medford-Somerville recently became the first urban educational institution in Massachusetts to be certified as an affiliate of the Bee Campus USA program.
With the help of the Tufts University Green Fund and the work of the Tufts Pollinator Initiative, Tufts University Medford-Somerville joins more than 200 other cities and campuses across the country united in improving their landscapes for pollinators.
Elizabeth Crone, professor of biology at Tufts University, is excited about the opportunities for student research and service-learning with the Medford-Somerville gardens.
Bee City USA and Bee Campus USA are initiatives of the Xerces Society for Invertebrate Conservation, a nonprofit organization based in Portland, Oregon, with offices across the country.
For information about Bee Campus USA, visit https://beecityusa.org.

title: Smallpox, cholera, influenza around Cambridge: How the region endured pandemics of the past
summary:
The good people of Boston, Cambridge and surrounding towns survived outbreaks of smallpox, diphtheria, yellow fever, cholera, polio and influenza.
Smallpox spread by face-to-face contact, or less often by contact with contaminated clothes and bedding.
At Camp Devens, an Army installation of 50,000 men 45 miles northwest of Boston, medical officers were overwhelmed by the onslaught of cases.
On this side of the river, Cambridge quickly had influenza cases of its own.
In November, a slight rise in influenza cases was reported, likely due to the crowds that gathered to celebrate the armistice with Germany on Nov. 11.

title: Bomb Cyclone Sets Record As Strongest October Storm Ever In Boston Area
summary:
BOSTON (CBS) — An intensifying coastal storm bombed out overnight and brought flooding rain and damaging winds to the area.
The definition of a ‘bomb cyclone’ is one that drops in pressure by at least 24 millibars in 24 hours or less.
As this storm intensified, the central pressure dropped to a new record for lowest pressure during October in our area.
Boston also smashed the record for lowest pressure during October at 975.3mb https://t.co/7mQan9KaSo — Eric Fisher (@ericfisher) October 17, 2019The strongest winds were along the east and south coast.

title: Here’s what to expect from Wednesday’s weather forecast
summary:
Wednesday may start on a dry note, but make sure you bring an umbrella for the evening.
A storm system will move into the area throughout the day, although some low level dry air may need to move out before rainfall really kicks in.
If you’re located west of the Worcester Hills, however, there is an increasing risk of rain by the afternoon.
This storm system will also bring strong winds, with gusts along the coast moving at up to about 45 miles per hour.

title: Unusually strong fall storm to bring a wind-driven drenching to southern New England

Isolated gusts to 60 mph can’t be ruled out over the Cape and Islands, with even a low risk of one or two 65 mph gusts.
Model differences in the exact storm track introduce some uncertainty as to where the worst of the impacts will occur.
Most storms that swing through New England this time of year are dubbed “nor’easters,” because their strong winds come from the northeast as a result of their offshore track (winds spin counterclockwise around storm low-pressure centers).

title: Confirmed Case Of Measles In Boston
summary:
BOSTON — After a Northeastern student who lives in Boston was diagnosed with measles Wednesday, health officials are warning people about potential exposure in 10 public places the infected person visited — from Logan Airport to Tatte's Bakery on Huntington Street to CVS on Massachusetts Avenue.
The Boston Public Health Commission said Thursday anyone who happened to be at those places could have been exposedThis is Boston's second confirmed case of measles in a city resident in the past three months.
Prior to that, there had been no cases of measles among Boston residents since 2013.
Anyone who was exposed and is unclear of their immunization status or begins to develop symptoms of measles should call their healthcare provider.
The CDC said there have been more than 314 measles cases across the country so far this year.

title: Bundle up! Potential snow and record cold coming to Boston, meteorologists say
summary:
This week will bring the possibility of snow in Boston during an evening commute and near-record cold on Wednesday, meteorologists said Sunday.
Reports anticipate precipitation between a dusting and 1 inch of snow, the first snow since a wet and windy Halloween storm rocked Western Massachusetts.
Shawn Kelley of Mill City Weather said there is the potential for icy roads with Tuesday’s snow, a week after cold, wet weather narrowly avoided freezing roads over.
“Our average for this month is 52 degrees, so to see a daytime high of 30 degrees, that’s uncommon for November,” Kelley said.
The snow projected for Tuesday would be far from the earliest snow on record in Boston, as Weather Service records show the first snow of 2009 falling on Oct. 19 in Boston.

title: These Companies Laid Off Massachusetts Workers in 2019
summary:
Massachusetts may be experiencing a low unemployment rate and a tight job market, but there are exceptions across the Bay State.
At 2.9 percent unemployment, a rate based on a monthly sample of households, the state “continues to experience strong job growth with an unemployment rate which has been at or below 3 percent for seven consecutive months,” Rosalin Acosta, labor chief for Gov.
Charlie Baker, said in a statement announcing preliminary August job numbers in September.
But more than a dozen companies — from an Ohio-based defense contractor to a Randolph beer distributor — have announced dozens of layoffs since the start of 2019, according to state data provided by Massachusetts labor officials.
Read more on the Boston Business Journal.

title: High Boston rent following tenants to Malden, Newton and beyond
summary:
If it seems like the high rents that are driving tenants out of Boston are following them to outlying communities, you’re not mistaken — Malden and Revere saw some of the area’s steepest rent hikes last year, studies show.
There is a definite demand for Boston and when prices get too high in Boston, people move to the next communities,” said Greg Vasil CEO & president of the Greater Boston Real Estate Board.
Cambridge is the most expensive city in the Boston area, where one-bedrooms rent for a median price of $2,650.
Revere rents are up 6.1% to a median price of $2,100 — the same price as Somerville.
“There are landlords out there who are willing to rent below market for really good tenants,” Vasil said.

title: Boston Resident Tests Positive For Measles
summary:
A Boston resident has tested positive for measles.
It's the first reported case in the city since 2013 and the third this year in Massachusetts, according to the Boston Public Health Commission.
The resident tested positive on Oct. 6, according to a Wednesday afternoon statement by the commission.
Measles symptom typically appear 21 days after exposure to the infection.
Getting vaccinated is the best way for everyone to protect themselves from measles," said Dr. Jennifer Lo, BPHC medical director.

title: Boston man arrested in connection to fatal October shooting

Officers from Boston, Brockton, and the State Police arrested James Nelson at 10:45 a.m., Boston police said in a statement.
Nelson is scheduled to be arraigned in West Roxbury District Court.
Officers responded at 3:48 a.m. on Saturday Oct. 26 to a report of a shooting near 81 Westminster Ave. in Roxbury, according to the statement.

title: NOAA just released its Winter Outlook. Here’s what it says about New England.
summary:
But New England can expect a milder season than normal, according to the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration.
Warmer-than-average temperatures are predicted for much of the U.S, the federal agency reports in its 2019-2020 Winter Outlook released Thursday by the Climate Prediction Center.
“Although below-average temperatures are not favored, cold weather is anticipated and some areas could still experience a colder-than-average winter,” the agency wrote in the outlook.
The outlook doesn’t include a projection of snowfall accumulations, since snow forecasts are generally not predictable more than a week in advance, according to NOAA.
And just because New England is predicted to see warmer-than-average temperatures doesn’t mean we won’t see the white stuff or potentially frigid temperatures.

title: Massachusetts home sales pick up in October amid steady demand
summary:
Pending home sales in Massachusetts picked up in October versus the same month in 2019, according to a new report from the Waltham-based Massachusetts Association of Realtors.
At the same time, too, the median prices of these pending single-family and condo sales were also up year over year.
Pending single-family sales have been up the past 12 months, the realtors said.
The number of pending condo sales was up 18.3 percent, to 2,113, and the median price 3.7 percent, to $368,000.
Pending condo sales have been up or flat 11 of the past 12 months.

An enhanced risk for severe storms, capable of producing damaging wind gusts and isolated tornadoes, is in place for portions of the Mid Atlantic tomorrow, October 31st.

Central and Western Massachusetts will see the highest rainfall totals.

title: DA: Boston College student who texted ‘go die’ to boyfriend charged in suicide
summary:
Suffolk District Attorney Rachael Rollins said Monday that Inyoung You, 21, of South Korea, is charged with involuntary manslaughter for her role in Urtula’s death.
Police determined You was “physically, verbally and psychologically abusive” toward Urtula after an investigation of his phone following his death, Rollins said.
You used threats of self-harm to control Urtula and the investigation revealed her manipulation escalated prior to Urtula’s suicide, Rollins said.
You, who was an economics major set to graduate from Boston College next May, withdrew from classes in August, the college confirmed.
You returned to South Korea following Urtula’s death and authorities said they are “cautiously optimistic” that she will willingly return to the U.S. to face charges.

title: OK, so when will we actually see our first snow of the season?
summary:
November is traditionally the month when southern New England (and northern) sees its first flakes and first measurable snowfall.
There have been years when we’ve had to wait much longer before the first measurable snowfall occurs, and a few years with October snow.
Depending on when the last snow occurred the previous winter and when the first snow occurs in the new one, there can be very long gaps or very short gaps between snow.
There can be large or small gaps between the final inch of snow in one season and the first inch in the next.
The longest season on record is 1977, when measurable snow began in mid-November and continued until the second week of May.

title: Boston Latin jumps out early, hold off Boston English
summary:
Boston Latin leads the series all-time by a 82-38-13 margin, including the past six straight.
Boston English (3-8) won the toss and deferred to the second half.
Peter Datish was perfect on the PAT and Latin led 9-0 with 3:46 left in the opening frame.
Boston English turned the ball over near midfield with 5:48 to go before halftime and Boston Latin took advantage.
The Bulldogs controlled the ball for over 11 minutes in the third quarter, allowing Latin only 49 seconds to run two plays yet English couldn’t garner any points.

summary:
First lady Melania Trump visited Boston today to highlight what’s being done to help babies born addicted to opiates — and the Herald was on the inside.
She toured Boston Medical Center’s Cuddling Assists in Lowering Maternal and Infant Stress program.
Here are highlights from the meeting:The focus at BMC is on infant stress from addiction.
Families are asking for help in substance use disorder — including tax help and food, but above all the mother-infant bond.
The governor’s wife said they are “all in” on the opiate addiction fight.

title: Is Massachusetts still at risk of EEE?
summary:
The latest cases triggered repeated warnings from state officials, who actively cautioned the public to take preventative steps to reduce personal EEE risk.
At this year’s peak, the outbreak put 35 communities at critical risk, while 53 and 121 others hit high and moderate risk warnings, respectively.
While officials rely on that first hard frost to help gauge the mosquito population, determining decreasing EEE risk, unlike increasing risk, is not necessarily straightforward, according to Brown.
Officials must also balance this knowledge with what they know from past experience when evaluating risk, Brown said.
What to know about next yearEach EEE outbreak in Massachusetts lasts approximately two to three years, according to the DPH.

title: Morgan Memorial Goodwill Industries holds its annual Thanks-for-Giving Dinner
summary:
Holiday spirit filled the room as hundreds of people danced, ate and celebrated at the annual Thanks-For-Giving event hosted by Morgan Memorial Goodwill Industries on Thanksgiving Eve.
A live band energized the crowd as 300 people in attendance enjoyed the sweet aroma of turkey, mashed potatoes, stuffing, cooked vegetables, apple cider and pumpkin pie.
“Goodwill works with a variety of people who face barriers to self-sufficiency,” said Joanne Hilferty, Goodwill’s CEO and president of Morgan Memorial Goodwill Industries.
“We work with them all year to help them get ready to go to work, whether it’s someone with a disability, or someone coming out of the correctional system, or someone who has been unemployed for a long time.”“The worth of the community is really in how we take care of those most vulnerable among us,” Attorney General Maura Healey told the audience.
“I can’t think of a place, an institution … that celebrates that more than Goodwill Morgan Memorial.”

title: Bundle up! Potential snow and record cold coming to Boston, meteorologists say
summary:
This week will bring the possibility of snow in Boston during an evening commute and near-record cold on Wednesday, meteorologists said Sunday.
Reports anticipate precipitation between a dusting and 1 inch of snow, the first snow since a wet and windy Halloween storm rocked Western Massachusetts.
Shawn Kelley of Mill City Weather said there is the potential for icy roads with Tuesday’s snow, a week after cold, wet weather narrowly avoided freezing roads over.
“Our average for this month is 52 degrees, so to see a daytime high of 30 degrees, that’s uncommon for November,” Kelley said.
The snow projected for Tuesday would be far from the earliest snow on record in Boston, as Weather Service records show the first snow of 2009 falling on Oct. 19 in Boston.

summary:

Boston Lyric Opera spokesman John Michael Kennedy told the Herald such a center would be welcome.
Last month the Massachusetts Convention Center Authority members voted to dispose of the Hynes Convention Center and sell or lease the property to pay for a $500 million expansion of the Boston Convention & Exhibition Center.
A study released last year by the Boston Planning & Redevelopment Authority highlights the need for a multipurpose performing arts center — something Boston currently lacks.

title: State House honors veterans who ‘didn’t hesitate to answer’ call of duty
summary:
Retired U.S. Army First Sergeant Gumersindo Gomez’s voice rang loud during a Veteran’s Day ceremony at the State House, echoing the day’s message of recognizing the immense sacrifice veterans have made for the country.
“This is an honor we carry for life because we felt the call of duty and didn’t hesitate to answer,” Gomez said.
Charlie Baker, Sen. Ed Markey, Attorney General Maura Healey and other public officials were on hand for the ceremony in Memorial Hall hosted by Francisco Urena, the state’s Veterans Affairs secretary.
Baker, who was met with a standing ovation from the crowd of veterans in military garb, Gold Star mothers and others, tried to quiet his warm welcome.
Gomez, a Vietnam veteran who has opened homes for homeless veterans in Springfield over his long post-military service career of advocacy, emphasized the message of the significant sacrifice millions have made when joining the military.

title: Charlie Baker signs ban on drivers using handheld phones
summary:
Massachusetts drivers will finally have to put down their phone — like everyone else in New England.
Charlie Baker signed legislation Monday afternoon banning handheld phone use by people operating vehicles, following years of debate over so-called hands-free driving legislation.
Drivers will still be allowed to use their phones if their car is stationary and not in a travel lane.
AdvertisementStill, supporters said the new law is an important step toward making streets safer for pedestrians, cyclists, and drivers alike.
This past summer, Maine passed a hands-free driving law, making Massachusetts — which has banned texting while driving for nearly a decade — the only state northeast of Pennsylvania without one.

Well, bye-bye, dancing hamsters, and hello personality with the third generation, 2020 Kia Soul.

The competition-less Kia Soul is here to stay and the sporty GT-Line Turbo proves why.

title: Latin Academy edges O’Bryant in City League finale
summary:
It was only fitting that a senior provided a critical play late to seal the final game of the season.
Latin Academy senior captain Rafael Cruz scored from 31 yards out in the fourth quarter to give the Dragons a 13-7 win over O’Bryant to claim the Boston City League North title on the road on Thanksgiving morning.
“We are a young team and it’s a good step for us,” said Dragons coach Rocco Zizza.
“It feels great,” Maffeo said after winning his second straight Thanksgiving contest over twin brother Luke Maffeo.
“Thanksgiving dinner tastes a lot better (after a win).”Latin Academy has now won all three Thanksgiving Day contests against O’Bryant and claimed its first Boston City title since winning the South in 2013.

title: Mass. RMV to close from Friday night until Tuesday morning for system upgrade
summary:
Those planning a trip to the RMV within the next few days need to make alternative plans for their visit.
The Registry of Motor Vehicles will be closed from 6 p.m. Friday through 7 a.m. Tuesday to allow for a system upgrade.
This means that all RMV locations, including at car dealerships, AAA, and insurance companies, will not be able to perform department services, including registrations and licenses, the department said on Twitter.
There also won’t be any safety or emissions inspections for vehicles, and there will be no internet or phone access for services during that time.

title: Hundreds of volunteers kick off holiday season food drive
summary:
Many hands made quick work Thursday of unloading thousands of meals at the Greater Boston Food Bank’s annual Chain of Giving event to feed families in time for Thanksgiving.
Mayor Martin Walsh and other officials formed a human chain with more than 200 other volunteers who transferred turkeys from the food bank’s loading dock to its 6,000-square-foot freezer.
“Hunger in the United States is an immoral act,” state Treasurer Deborah Goldberg said.
“It doesn’t belong here.”Catherine D’Amato, the food bank’s president and CEO, said one in 11 Eastern Massachusetts residents is food insecure.
We have one in six Bostonians struggling with some form of food insecurity,” Walsh said.

title: Asbestos cleanup underway in Downtown Crossing after pipe leak
summary:
Crews were still working Sunday night to clean asbestos from a downtown Boston intersection a day after an underground steam pipe sprayed material containing the substance over the road, according to authorities.
Police and fire officials closed off several streets near 99 Summer St. in Downtown Crossing after a steam pipe leak spread the substance around the area.
“We have dedicated crews working around the clock to restore the area to normal service,” said a spokeswoman from Veolia, the water, waste and energy company that operates the pipe.
Boston fire officials said hazmat crews responded to the area of 99 Summer St. around 1:15 a.m. Saturday after a steam leak left an unknown debris in the area.
The source of the asbestos is still under investigation, as is the cause of the event, according to Veolia.

title: When 2019 Daylight Saving Time Ends In MA: When Clocks Turn Back
summary:
Daylight Saving Time ends on Sunday, Nov. 3, in Massachusetts, which means earlier sunsets and shorter afternoons.
Massachusetts has looked at the possibility of doing away with Daylight Saving Time, but a special commission that examined it suggested not to make a change unless the rest of the Northeast does.
Not every state follows Daylight Saving Time.
Brief History of Daylight Saving TimeBen Franklin is credited by many for being the first person to propose the concept of Daylight Saving Time centuries before it was implemented.
The practice of Daylight Saving Time has been used sporadically in the United States since World War I.

title: Want to see Mercury parade across the sun Monday? Here’s what to know.
summary:
CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla. (AP) — Mercury is putting on a rare celestial show next week, parading across the sun in view of most of the world.
The entire 5 ½-hour event will be visible, weather permitting, in the eastern U.S. and Canada, and all Central and South America.
Unlike its 2016 transit, Mercury will score a near bull’s-eye this time, passing practically dead center in front of our star.
Earthlings get treated to just 13 or 14 Mercury transits a century.
Although the trek will appear slow, Mercury will zoom across the sun at roughly 150,000 mph.

summary:
Troquet on South, Boston’s premiere destination for modern French cuisine, has announced a Beaujolais and Cassoulet dinner on November 21st, 2019 from 5:00PM-10:00PM.
In France, the third Thursday in November is marked as “Beaujolais Nouveau Day” which celebrates the release of the new Beaujolais wine at 12:01AM and is often accompanied by festivals, music, fireworks, and parties throughout the country.
Embracing its French roots, Troquet is bringing the traditional French fête of the 2019 Beaujolais release to Boston!
Offered by the glass or the bottle, Beaujolais is a French wine packed with fruity flavors that is lively and easy to drink.
Troquet’s Executive Chef Tyler Stout will also prepare a Classic Cassoulet, a slow cooked French casserole available in the dining room or the bar.

summary:

Even holding a phone or other device while driving is breaking the new hands-free law, the statue states.
State police don’t yet have data on how many warnings and citations they have issued for the hands-free law, according to spokesman David Procopio, who added that will be calculated in about a week.
Talking on a handheld device caused just over 1,000 crashes during that time period, while using a hands-free device caused just under 300, the data shows.
Those under 18 years old are still not allowed to use electronics behind the wheel at all, even while using hands-free mode.

Graduated Boston University. While Not Reporting
summary:
The Bay State is receiving $500,000 in initial federal funding to respond to the coronavirus threat, the U.S. Department of Health and Human Services announced on Wednesday.
“State and local governments are the backbone of our public health system,” HHS Secretary Alex Azar said in a statement.
“CDC is committed to working with state, local, tribal and territorial public health departments to mitigate community spread of novel coronavirus in this nation,” CDC Director Robert Redfield said in a statement.
These states and regions will use the funding for monitoring travelers, data management, lab equipment, supplies, staffing, shipping, infection control and surge staffing.
CDC will also award $10 million to states and regions to implement “coronavirus surveillance across the U.S., building on existing influenza activities and other surveillance systems.”Herald wire services were used in this report.

In fact, one source told KSR’s own Matt Jones that it remains “very likely” the Kentucky signee still ends up in Lexington.
Sources tell KSR that the Kentucky coaching staff was in positive communication with the five-star signee regarding his future in Lexington in recent days.
The five-star guard announced his commitment to Kentucky back on September 14 before signing with the school on November 14.

title: MA Rents Rose Slightly In 2019
summary:
BOSTON — The cost of rent is on the rise across the nation, according to the first National Rent Report of 2020, compiled by Apartment List.
Rents increased 1.4 percent from December 2018 to December 2019, although some cities actually are bucking the trend and seeing rent costs fall.
Boston slightly exceeded the national increase, showing the median rent for a two-bedroom apartment increase by 1.5 percent from December 2018 to December 2019.
Read more about the National Rent Report methodology.
According to the report, Mesa, Arizona, had the fastest year-over-year rent growth among cities with a population of 250,000 or more.

title: Winter Solstice, Ursid Meteors 2019: When To Watch In MA
summary:
For anyone stretching their winter solstice revelry into the night, here's a bonus: The Ursid meteor shower peaks overnight Saturday and Sunday.
The winter solstice occurs at the moment the North Pole tilts the farthest away from the sun.
The winter solstice, the oldest-known winter celebration, is derived from the Latin word "solstitium," which means "sun standing still."
Several of the rituals associated with Christmas — dinner feasts, gift-giving and decorative wreaths, for example — are rooted in pagan winter solstice rituals.
It may surprise you that the earliest sunsets and latest sunrises don't occur on the winter solstice.

summary:

“With heavy rain in progress, we are keeping a close eye on river levels across the region,” the National Weather Service tweeted.
“Due to flooding, Morrissey Boulevard in Boston is closed in both directions between JFK and Freeport,” state police said.
“Winds of between 20 mph to 30 mph, with gusts up to 50 mph, are forecast,” the Steamship Authority tweeted.
Rain is expected to return Tuesday, along with a chance of snow in the late afternoon, forecasters wrote.

title: Boston City Council expands sanctuary city policy
summary:
City councilors have moved to expand a sanctuary city policy by imposing new limits in how Boston Police can handle immigration matters, limiting their ability to share information in civil deportation cases after revelations cops kept working with the feds despite city policies barring it.
“Our police department has a hard enough job without enforcing failed immigration policy,” said District 8 City Councilor Josh Zakim, the lead sponsor on the bill.
City councilors on Wednesday unanimously approved amendments to the city’s 5-year-old Trust Act, further limiting the role police can play in situations that deal with civil immigration matters.
City councilors scrambled to tie up loose ends in a marathon meeting on Wednesday — their last of the session and the final meeting ever for the four outgoing city councilors: District 9 City Councilor Mark Ciommo, District 5 City Councilor Tim McCarthy, District 8 City Councilor Zakim and City Councilor-at large Althea Garrison.
City councilors also passed new provisions for wetlands protection that bill sponsor and City Councilor-at large Michelle Wu said will provide “climate resiliency and climate justice” as the city continues to develop.

title: NOAA just released its Winter Outlook. Here’s what it says about New England.
summary:
But New England can expect a milder season than normal, according to the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration.
Warmer-than-average temperatures are predicted for much of the U.S, the federal agency reports in its 2019-2020 Winter Outlook released Thursday by the Climate Prediction Center.
“Although below-average temperatures are not favored, cold weather is anticipated and some areas could still experience a colder-than-average winter,” the agency wrote in the outlook.
The outlook doesn’t include a projection of snowfall accumulations, since snow forecasts are generally not predictable more than a week in advance, according to NOAA.
And just because New England is predicted to see warmer-than-average temperatures doesn’t mean we won’t see the white stuff or potentially frigid temperatures.

title: The minimum wage in Massachusetts is going up this week. Here’s what you need to know.
summary:
Here’s what you need to know:How the minimum wage changes:First things first, the Massachusetts minimum wage, which increased from $11 to $12 last year, will go up again to $12.75 an hour in 2020.
It’s the second in the series of five annual minimum wage hikes.
By 2023, the Bay State will be joined by California, Connecticut, and Washington, D.C. — and parts of New York — with a $15 minimum wage.
There are, however, a few exceptions to the state’s standard minimum wage rate.
AdvertisementAlong with the standard minimum wage, the tipped minimum wage will increase Wednesday from $4.35 to $4.95 an hour (it had been $3.75 when the “grand bargain” was passed).

“This was a very complicated, evolving system,” Simpson said.
“There’s a strong clipper system on Friday that could bring some additional snowfall, but it’s a little uncertain,” Rossio said.

title: Report: Home prices hit records for December
summary:
The Greater Boston Association of Realtors reported Wednesday that the region saw 21 percent and 18 percent increases in single-family homes and condos sales volume, respectively, in December.
Sales and prices were up for both condos and single-family homes in Massachusetts, according to two reports released Wednesday.
“Despite a slight dip in single-family sales compared to 2018, the streak of the median sale price increasing on a year-over-year basis continues.
The last time the year-end median single-family home price declined was at the tail end of the housing market crash in 2011.
The median sales price for a single-family home hit $605,000, a record high for the month and a 3.4 percent increase over December 2018.

title: What Were the Biggest Stories in Massachusetts for 2019?
summary:
2019's biggest stories in Massachusetts played out in the courtroom.
The state's highest court upheld Michelle Carter's manslaughter conviction for sending her suicidal boyfriend a barrage of text messages urging him to kill himself.
And Massachusetts' attorney general launched fresh legal challenges to the Trump administration's immigration policies.
The "House of Cards" actor's accuser invoked his Fifth Amendment right not to testify about text messages from the night of the alleged encounter.
Responding to growing concerns about the health effects of vaping, Massachusetts became the first state to ban flavored tobacco and nicotine vaping products.

summary:
More than 200 soldiers from the Massachusetts Army and Air National Guard marched 4.6 miles from Dorchester to Boston Children’s Hospital to deliver toys, games and gift cards to kids staying at the hospital over the holiday season.
Stephen Fiola of the Army National Guard said that in addition to the gifts carried in soldiers’ sacks, two trucks filled with presents followed the Santa stand-ins during the ninth annual National Guard Toy Ruck March.

title: 4 Hospitalized, 16 Displaced in Overnight House Fire in Hull
summary:
Four people were injured and sixteen displaced Friday during an early morning house fire in Hull, Massachusetts.
Hull Fire Chief Chris Russo said crews received a call about the blaze just before 4 a.m. and responded to a multi-family home located at 30 D St.
When they arrived, heavy fire was coming from the first-floor windows and attic of the 4-unit building.
Flames were in the walls and crews had a difficult time gaining access to the fire, Russo said.
The sixteen people who are now displaced were able to escape the blaze before firefighters arrived.

title: Mother, 2 children dead in ‘likely’ double murder-suicide
summary:
A mother “likely” took her own life after throwing her two young children off a Roxbury parking garage in a Christmas Day double murder-suicide that Suffolk DA Rachael Rollins said demonstrates the “urgency” of addressing mental health issues.
Rollins identified the mother as 40-year-old Erin Pascal of West Roxbury, and her two children, Allison, 4, and Andrew, 1-and-a-half years old.
She said the tragedy at the Renaissance Park Garage on Northeastern University’s campus happened between 1:25 and 1:35 p.m. Wednesday.
Boston College student Alexander Urtula leapt to his death from the parking garage on May 20, hours before his graduation ceremony.

title: Ban on vape sales in Massachusetts ends Wednesday — what happens next?
summary:
Governor Charlie Baker’s ban on vape sales will lift Wednesday, nearly three months after it started amid an outbreak of vaping-related lung injuries.
Baker’s emergency ban on all nicotine and marijuana vape sales will expire, but the products will likely not return to stores right away.
That is also when a new 75 percent excise tax on nicotine vaping products will begin.
In Massachusetts, 39 percent reported vaping only THC, 21 percent reported vaping both nicotine and THC, and 31 percent said they vaped nicotine only.
Along the border in New Hampshire and Maine, sales of nicotine and cannabis vaping products have boomed, with some retailers logging a doubling or more of sales.

summary:
A construction worker was killed Saturday morning while setting up for First Night Boston in Copley Square, according to Boston Police and a First Night Boston spokesman.
The man was an employee of a company, United Staging & Rigging, assisting First Night with setup for the annual event, according to a First Night Boston spokesman.
“We are devastated by today’s tragic accident that occurred while constructing a lighting tower for the First Night stage in Copley Square.
“This morning there was a fatal accident in Copley Square at setup for First Night Boston involving a construction worker,” read a statement from First Night Boston.
“My heart goes out to the family and friends of the victim in Copley Square this afternoon,” Boston Mayor Martin Walsh said in a statement issued by his office.

title: Here is how much snow fell in Massachusetts during the Dec. 17 storm
summary:
A winter storm dumped snow across several communities in Massachusetts Tuesday, bringing with it sleet, slippery road conditions as well as school closures and delays.
Communities in Northern Berkshire County saw some of the most snow in the state, nearly 4 inches.
Cities and towns near the New Hampshire and Vermont state lines, as well as Central Worcester County, saw around 2 inches of snow, with as much as 3.7 inches reported in Heath.
Central and Eastern Massachusetts saw considerably less snow.
A little bit more than an inch of snow was reported at Boston Logan International Airport.

Spanish. Alexi'S Professional Experience Encompasses Print
summary:
Doctors from Brigham and Women’s Hospital are asking flu patients to consider other treatment options before coming to the overcrowded emergency department with the end of flu season nowhere in sight.
“Patients with cold and flu symptoms may not need to come to the emergency department for evaluation,” said Baugh at a press conference on Thursday.
He said patients should come into the emergency department only if they are experiencing dehydration, confusion or shortness of breath.
Flu symptoms like fatigue, muscle aches or runny nose can drag on for weeks, and employees are advised to stay home from work for five to seven days, said Sax.
If hospital overcrowding becomes too severe, discharges are expedited, patients are moved into alternate spaces and on-call staff come in for shifts.

title: Sunday snow forecast could impact Thanksgiving travelers
authors: Stefan Geller Is A General Assignment Reporter At The Boston Herald. An Arlington Resident
He Previously Worked For The Weekly Newspaper The Needham Times.
summary:
“Anyone traveling this weekend is advised to closely monitor the forecast,” said MassDOT Highway Administrator Jonathan Gulliver.
In addition to rain and snow, forecasters wrote that New Englanders can expect to see heavy winds blow through the region as well, especially from Sunday night into Monday.
“We may see winds gusting 20-25 mph, 30-35 mph or more along the coast,” forecasters wrote.
However, forecasters wrote that it is still too soon to generate a precise forecast as weather patterns continue to shift.
“A high degree of uncertainty remains regarding the track and strength of the low as well as the thermal profile that will determine changes between precipitation types,” forecasters wrote.

title: Arrest Made 2 Weeks After South Boston Hit-and-Run That Injured a Woman
summary:
A man who allegedly hit a 60-year-old woman at a crosswalk in South Boston and took off two weeks ago was arrested Tuesday, police announced.
Investigators believe Murphy was looking at his phone when he hit the woman, who was in a crosswalk on Day Boulevard near K Street, with his Lincoln Town Car about 7:17 a.m., police said.
One of the car's sideview mirrors was damaged in the crash, according to police, and Murphy replaced it, obtaining a rental car as well.
It wasn't immediately clear if Murphy had an attorney who could speak to the charges, which police said he was facing at his arraignment Tuesday at South Boston District Court.
The woman was taken to an area hospital with serious injuries but she is expected to recover, police said.

title: Coronavirus Confirmed in Boston Student Is First Case in Mass.
summary:
A university student who recently traveled back to Boston from Wuhan, China, has been diagnosed as the first Massachusetts resident with the new coronavirus, state health officials said Saturday.
He is currently quarantined at his home and will continue to be isolated until he is cleared by public health officials, according to Saturday's news release.
UMass Boston confirmed in an email message to its community Saturday afternoon that a student had tested positive for the novel coronavirus.
That case was confirmed late Friday night, health officials said.
The UMass Boston student returned from China on Jan. 28, and sought medical attention for a runny nose the following day.
